Description: Body sherd (mended from three fragments) of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery dinos; interior reserved; exterior, creamy slip: three friezes, separated by simple bands, of goats and deer grazing to right; upper one has head, forelegs and hind hoof remaining, with rising triangle as filling ornament; in middle frieze, deer (only rump and hindlegs of deer missing) and goat(?), shoulder, neck and head of goat missing); rising roundel and triangle, swastikas and rosettes as filling ornament; below, goat (shoulder, tip of ear and horn remaining); undetermined motif as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as being in the style of the Würzburg chalices, but dated later than those chalices because she considers the style of the drawing to be debased and because of the elementary and isolated interior decoration (Lemos 1991, 72-3). According to Lemos, the sherd may come from either a dinos or an oinochoe since it is unusual to have three or four friezes on dinoi (Lemos 1991, 19-20) but Williams points out that Wild Goat Style dinoi, because they are unslipped on their interior, are often mistaken for oinochoai (Williams 2006a, 128). British Museum 1888, 0601.499.e, 1924,1201.20, 1888,0601.460.e, 1888,0601.460.f, 1888,0601.459 and 1888, 0601.460.g, which all belong to one dinos, clearly show that the vessel has at least four friezes. It is quite possible that 1888,601.458 too belonged to a similar vessel.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 19, 73, p. 245, no. 282, pl. 35)
Price 1924 / Pottery of Naukratis (p. 216, pl. X, no. 1)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (p. 138, no. 691)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0007) (phase 2)
